Description:
Food deserts are areas where people lack access to nutritious foods such as fruits and vegetables from grocery stores. It is possible that the easier options available to these people are convenience stores and fast food restaurants. Often, food from these facilities are marked as having high glycemic index and loads. Over time, high calorie diets could cause increases in weight gain and the risk of chronic disease development. Residents of poorer neighborhoods typically have higher BMI and BMI increased when shopping in impoverished areas. This could be an implication of the relationship between high calorie diets and low income neighborhoods. Additionally, these neighborhoods could be at higher risk of both chronic disease and cancer. These conclusions can be drawn from the growing body of research linking cancers to high glycemic index and load, coupled with our understanding of obesity on chronic disease risk.
Throughout this project let’s explore the relationships between cancer rates, low income low access populations, and fast food density.

Figure 1 illustrates age-adjusted cancer incidence rates per 100,00 people per County for North Carolina. Lighter colors indicate lower incidence rate. Viewing left to right, Mcdowell, New Hanover, and Northampton are not accounted for within the map.
The Cancer rates data include invasive cancers only and are age adjusted. Age adjusting data ensures that age does not skew the data. For example, older people are more likely to get cancer. It is important not to mistake higher incidence rates coming from low income low access populations rather than the high percentage of elderly. Swain, Anson, and Onslow all show higher incidence rate and appear darker visually. Most counties have incidence rates above 400 and the trend to lean toward the upper end of the incidence rate scale.

Figure 2 illustrates fast food density per County for North Carolina. Lighter colors indicate lower fast food density. Viewing left to right, Mcdowell and New Hanover are not accounted for within the map.
Low income low access populations are classified as being 200% or more below the federal poverty level. These people don’t have access to supermarkets within 1 mile for urban areas and 10 miles for rural areas.
Swain and Dare both show more fast food restaurants per 1,000 people. Most counties fall between 0 and 2, and lean toward the lower end of the access scale. There is not another state to compare data to, it could be that the two highest states are outliers that raise the range of percentages for NC.

Figure 3 illustrates the percent of the population classified as low income low access at 1 and 10 miles per County for North Carolina. Lighter colors indicate lower population percentages. Viewing left to right, Mcdowell and New Hanover are not accounted for within the map.
Bertie and Hyde both have a higher percentage of the population classified as low income and low access. Hyde in particular shows 30% of the population as low income and low access.
There is not a lot of variation between counties, this could be because of the fast food market. Having a restaurant density that is too high could result in high competition, naturally lowering the density.

Figure 4 and 5 illustrate the percent of the population classified as low income, low access at 1 and 10 miles (Figure 4) or fast food density (Figure 5) plotted over the age-adjusted cancer incidence rates per 100,00 people per County for North Carolina. Lighter blue indicates lower incidence rate. Higher fast food density is marked by darker red and larger points. The size of the points corresponds with the population of individuals that are low income and low access. Viewing left to right, Mcdowell and New Hanover and Northampton are not accounted for rates and fast food and Mcdowell and New Hanover are not accounted for access in the map.
Within both of the maps there is not a clear relationship between the variables. Some counties have high incidence rate and low fast food density while others show high incidence rate and high fast food density. This is the same can be said for incidence rates and low income low access.

Figure 6 shows linear correlations between low income low access and incidence rates. Figure 7 shows linear correlations between fast food density and incidence rates.
Figures 6 and 7 both show linear correlations of .05. Positive correlations range from 0 to 1, .05 indicates a very weak correlation. There is little to no linear correlation between the variables but the data points are clustered. This could imply more complex relationships not visible when correlating linearly.

The most important step in finding solutions is understanding what classified a community as low income low access. It could be not having enough stores in the area, not having transportation, or having enough money. If there are not enough stores in the area then encouraging development of a walmart could be beneficial.
Canned vegetables have nutrients comparable to fresh vegetables. Food banks and non-profits could target these areas as they often have supplies of canned goods. This could decrease the risk of chronic disease development and increase the health of individuals in the community.
Encouraging community gardening would also be beneficial. Even if given more options, people might still choose less nutrient dense foods. Putting work into a community garden would encourage the use of its harvests.
Some limitations to accuracy include the years data was taken from. Rates data was taken from 2017-2020 whereas fast food data was from 2010. This 10 year gap leaves room for a large possible change in population which could result in less accurate findings. Additionally, looking into different types of non-linear correlation could improve the understanding of the relationships explored.
Within this work, the relationship between low income low access populations and high calorie low nutrient diets has been inferred from previous studies. Food swamps however, by definition, account for areas with greater concentrations of less nutritious, high calorie, low nutrient foods. Using food swamp datasets as opposed to low income low access datasets in comparison with cancer rates could give a more accurate conclusion.
